bug.author: GPhilo
bug.summary: fitLine returns wrong line for nearly-horizontal points
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h5>System information (version)</denchmark-h>


OpenCV => 3.4.3
Operating System / Platform => Windows 10 1903
Compiler => MSVC 1916

<denchmark-h:h5>Detailed description</denchmark-h>

Fitting a line passing through almost-horizontal points via cv::fitLine results in a wrong line parameters vector.
<denchmark-h:h5>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>

#include <vector>
#include <iostream>
#include <opencv2/imgproc.hpp>

int main()
{
    std::vector<cv::Point> points = { 
        {432,654},
        {370,656},
        {390,656},
        {410,656},
        {348,658},
    };

    cv::Vec4f lineParam;
    cv::fitLine(points, lineParam, cv::DIST_L1, 0, 0.01, 0.01);
    std::cout << lineParam << std::endl;
}
Running the code above prints . The first two values,  and  are for a unit vector pointing approximately 45Â° down from the 0, while the expected result would have it closer to 0 (the points are almost perfectly aligned horizontally).
Values for  and  are taken from <denchmark-link:https://docs.opencv.org/2.4/modules/imgproc/doc/structural_analysis_and_shape_descriptors.html#fitline>https://docs.opencv.org/2.4/modules/imgproc/doc/structural_analysis_and_shape_descriptors.html#fitline</denchmark-link>

<denchmark-h:hr></denchmark-h>

<denchmark-h:h3>Update:</denchmark-h>

If I use cv::DIST_L2 instead of cv::DIST_L1 for the distance function, the line is correctly estimated:
<denchmark-code>[0.999247, -0.038801, 390, 656]
</denchmark-code>

It would seem, then that the issue is related to using the L1 distance.
